indicators.justification:
Australia submits National Inventory Reports to the UNFCCC, who determined, "..the reporting is complete, transparent and thus adhering to the UNFCCC reporting guidelines on BRs."pg 7 (1)

This information contained in the report is published online by the Australian Government Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources through a series of web links. (2-5) Source data is available in the form of a downloadable excel spreadsheet.

The UNFCCC reported data is published online and contains unique identifiers to cross-reference inventories and sources. This data is somewhat fragmented, requiring a level of compilation/organisation from the data user.  

Sources:

1. United Nations, Framework Convention on Climate Change, July 2020, Report on the Technical Review of the Fourth Biennial Report of Australia, https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/trr2020_AUS.pdf


2. Australian Government, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, National Greenhouse Gas Inventory: Quarterly updates, https://www.industry.gov.au/data-and-publications/national-greenhouse-gas-inventory-quarterly-updates

3. Australian Government, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, State and Territory Greenhouse Gas Inventories - https://www.industry.gov.au/data-and-publications/state-and-territory-greenhouse-gas-inventories

4. Australian Government, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, National Inventory by Economic Sector, https://www.industry.gov.au/data-and-publications/national-inventory-by-economic-sector

5. Australian Government, Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources, National Greenhouse Gas Inventory – Paris Agreement Inventory - https://ageis.climatechange.gov.au/

indicators.justification:
The Australian Government, Department of Agriculture, Water, and Environment largely focuses on publishing data relating to Emissions reporting and projections.1 

There is no evidence of a coordinated National effort to publish climate vulnerability data. Reports are available through the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), however, any data available is not specific to Australia and is freely available already.2 

Open data related to climate vulnerability can be found through the open data repository,3 but this is by no means an exhaustive resource in relation to climate vulnerability. 

There is interest from non-government research institutions collecting data on Indigenous localised observations of climate change and strategies of adaptation, there is no evidence of this data being integrated into any national reporting or strategy.4  

Sources: 

1. Australian Government, Department of Agriculture, Water, and Environment: Climate science and data, https://www.environment.gov.au/climate-change/climate-science-data

2. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change: Reports, https://www.ipcc.ch/about/preparingreports/ 

3. Australian Government, Open Data Repository, https://data.gov.au/

4. Nursey-Bray, Melissa. Old ways for new days: Australian Indigenous peoples and climate change in Local Environment: The International Journal of Justice and Sustainability. (Vol. 24, 2019), https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13549839.2019.1590325

indicators.justification:
Assessing the Transparency Register, the published data is broken down into a simple format of embedded tables that can be filtered, each donor is hyperlinked to a separate page containing unique identifiers. The tables are downloadable in excel format also. 

The Transparency Register provides receipts of donations over the reporting threshold, and debts that are reimbursed through public funding. Membership dues are not disclosed.

A deal of specificity is lacking in the published data, detailed breakdowns of spending, liabilities, assets, and membership dues are not available. This does not appear to be a case of selective publishing but rather insufficient source data to begin with as described by social science researchers Sally Young and Joo-Cheong Tham,

"While, at the Federal level, the parties in Australia do provide annual disclosure returns to the AEC, these statements certainly do not disclose the full details of the parties' income, assets or spending. Because disclosure is required not in order to permit the policing of legal limits but only as a matter of general principle, these statements are insubstantial and incomplete." pg  99 (1) 

Sources:

1. Young, Sally and Tham, Joo-Cheong. Political finance in Australia: A skewed and secret system. School of Social Sciences The Australian National University, report no 7, 2006. https://apo.org.au/sites/default/files/resource-files/2006-11/apo-nid3933.pdf

Independent Parliamentary Expense Authority, https://www.ipea.gov.au/pwe

indicators.justification:
Austender is Australia's public procurement website, it's function is described as:

AusTender is the Australian Government procurement information system. It provides a central web-based facility for:

"Publishing of all publicly available Government Approaches to Market (ATM's), Annual Procurement Plans (APPs), standing offer arrangements and contracts awarded. Electronic distribution of ATM documentation and addenda. Secure lodgement of tender responses."1

While procurement Plans are available in spreadsheet format, the awarded tender data assessed shows no evidence of machine-readable formats available. 

While the website appears to be updated, reporting from The Guardian has indicated that the Federal government is not entirely transparent with publishing all procurement activities2, as such there is no definitive way to prove that all data (most recent procurement activities) are up to date or even published. The most recent record is within the week of the research being conducted.

Transparency International Australia, in their submission to a review of the Australian Public Sector, point to a series of reviews and audits into Austender in summarising the lack of "accuracy, fullness, and comparability of AusTender data."pg 7 (3).

The Australian Finance Department completed its compliance review of Procurement Activities and "continue to review the use and value of the OCDS compliant dataset on an ongoing basis." They have committed to "increasing" compliance with OCDS.4

indicators.justification:
The Public Data Policy Statement (2015) is a National mandate for all Australian Public Service agencies and their workers. Individual State and Territory governments have additional open data policies.1

The Digital Transformation Agency, the portfolio responsible for the execution of the Open Data Policy (2017) had a budget of AUD$135 940 000 for the period of July 2019 to June 2020. Open Data projects were not itemised in the budget report.2 

Former Australian Prime Minister (2015-2018) Malcolm Turnball, was the signiatory to the Public Data Policy Statement (2015)1 and publicly committed to the Open Data Initiative through a media release.3 

Locating recent examples of political advocacy is difficult. Notable reporting has indicated that the current Office of Prime Minister and Cabinet, led by Prime Minister Scott Morrison (2018-Present), has demonstrated consistent reluctancy in meeting FOI deadlines.4

indicators.justification:
The Data Skills and Capability in the Public Service document lists opportunities available for all Australian public servants in technical and non-technical roles; to increase their literacy and/or become experts in data management. These include Fellowships, potential financial support to undertake relevant tertiary education, online modules, and short courses. These appear to be optional and dependent on branch approval. 

Anecdotal information gathered through personal correspondence with ex-Australian public servants suggests that although there are efforts in some government departments to formalise data literacy standards into position descriptions this is not uniform across the public sector.

indicators.justification:
Common identifiers such as name (organisation/department/policy/project etc) and date (usually a year) tend to be consistent across published data. The issue is the lack of fully open data sets, that is, data available in complete form and downloadable in a machine-readable format; and the incompleteness of the data published. Data relating to FOI compliance is a prime example of this, it isn't available in meaningful time-frames or in complete form and the annual reporting, while broadly covering all compliance areas, does so with the most general of statistics.

indicators.justification:
The Australian Government agreed to consider a beneficial ownership register at the UK Anti-Corruption Summit in May of 2016, re-affirming this commitment in December 2016 with a consultation paper following in January 2017, 5. (1) At a glance stakeholder responses generally advocate for a single register, with varying opinions on its theoretical degree of 'openness.2 A 2018 Parliamentary review of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) sought a progress update on the register consultation and ASIC responded that there was a mixed response from stakeholders and that beneficial owner issues are addressed by existing shareholder regulation pg. 36-37. (3) Transparency International Australia refutes this, arguing, "Australia's corporate regulatory system is not up to scratch", in calling for a free and open beneficial ownership register.4    

Sources:

1. Australian Government, January 2017, Increasing Transparency of the Beneficial Ownership of Companies: Consultation Paper, https://treasury.gov.au/sites/default/files/2019-03/C2017-004_CP_Increasing_Transparency_of_the_Beneficial_Ownership_of_Companies.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Australian Government has a website accessibility requirement that all government web pages be WCAG 2.0 in compliance with the technical standard developed under the Web Accessibility Initiative of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). This requirement falls under the Discrimination Act (1992). This includes the National Archive and all records are available in downloadable pdf form. Their website does not specify site-specific accessibility standards for paper-only records.1 

Government agencies must follow compliance guidelines and conduct regular reviews, the Australian Human Rights Commission investigates complaints relating to violations in this context.2

indicators.justification:
The Digital Continuity Policy (2020) (DC2020), aim is to, "promote a consistent approach to information governance across the Australian Government and within individual agencies. It applies to government information, data and records, as well as systems, services and processes, including those created or delivered by third parties on behalf of Australian Government agencies."pg.3 (1)

The Policy has a clear transformation Framework with key deliverables and reporting timelines. It consists an Accountability Framework where, "Agencies are required to create and manage their information as a public resource in accordance with the Archives Act 1983 and the Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013, as well as the Protective Security Policy Framework, Commonwealth Resource Management Framework and internal corporate controls."pg.7,(2) The Annual Report from The Digital Transformation Agency (2019-2020), responsible for delivering policy objectives has indicated that while some work has been put on hold due to Covid-19, they have largely met their yearly goals, and "digital transformation" is ongoing with the objective to meet the Transformation Roadmap by 2025,pg. 25-50 (3)

indicators.justification:
The Australian Productivity Commission's inquiry report on Data Availability and Use (2017), found Australia's Privacy Act and privacy provisions contained within sector-specific legislation to be inadequate and outdated in the context of the current digital landscape. The report found data management frameworks to be inconsistent and that a considerable culture shift was needed to implement productive change, describing efforts to implement contemporary data sharing practices as, "overall, and despite positive sentiment for some time now, progress has to date been insufficient, given the broad effects possible across the social economy from the massive growth in digital data."pg 25.1

In response to the Australian Productivity Commission's inquiry report on Data Availability and Use (2017), the Data Availability and Transparency Bill 2020 was drafted.2 

The Bill proposes a data-sharing framework where accredited users and entities are able to access data through automated channels, replacing the current ad-hoc system subject to the somewhat subjective interpretation of the current privacy laws and the need to verify individual credentials at every engagement with a bureaucratic department.

indicators.justification:
While a framework exists, recent developments in the complexity of data ecosystems means that The Australian legal, regulatory, and policy landscape offers a mechanism for data protection and a mechanism for the responsible stewardship of personal data but only partially.1 

The Privacy Act (1988) applies to Government Agencies and Private Organisations with an annual turnover greater than AUD $3000,000. Political Parties and Small businesses are excluded from the Act but may be required to comply with jurisdictional or Telecommunication, Healthcare, or National Security legislation.2 The Privacy Act centers around 12 Privacy Principles and entities are required to self-determine "reasonable" levels of self-governed compliance based on their organisational structure.3

The Privacy Act applies to the Commonwealth of Australia, it's important to note the States and Territories of Australia have separate Data and Privacy laws that organisations operating within those jurisdictions must adhere to in addition to Commonwealth Law.

A review of the Australian Privacy Act began in October of 2020 with an issue paper,4 outlining the scope of the consultation. Notably, this includes consideration of a 2014 Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) report that found a statutory privacy tort to be included to provide an avenue for Australian citizens to pursue legal recourse for privacy breaches.5

indicators.justification:
The Primary language is English, all laws and documents published by the local, state and federal government are published in this language. The Indigenous Aboriginal people of Australia have over 250 languages, none are currently recognised as a National language.1 Indigenous lobby groups are calling for Indigenous Data Sovereignty and the government is considering a specific Indigenous Data Strategy, (pg 13.  Data Sharing and Release Legislative Reforms Discussion Paper)2, however, as all State records are held in English this is unlikely to have an effect on the language data is released in. 

Sources:

indicators.justification:
In 2015 the Australian Government laid out an Open Data Policy through its Public Data Policy Statement,1, that sought to release all non-sensitive data as open by default, within the confines of related laws and regulations and sought to collaborate with the private sector and researchers to optimise its dissemination and value. While Data.gov.au,2 (established in 2011) provided a central, free repository utilised by Federal, State, and Local governments, the Policy recommendations were not universally implemented consistently. Some local councils and jurisdictions implemented their own Open Data Policies with different objectives and targeted KPI's relating to the number of data sets released, to either their own sub-page on the data.gov.au page or their own separate platform. As observed by Researchers Suneel Jethani and Dale Leorke during a three-year study of the Victorian State Governments Open Data implementation, 3, a fractuous approach to consistent and quality data release exists within the State Public Service, representative of the National Landscape.

indicators.justification:
Under the Public Governance, Performance and Accountability Act 2013.1 and the Charter of Budget Honesty Act 1998;2 All government agencies and departments are required to report their annual reports and budgets/expenditures. Since 2018, these reports have been published on the Australian Government Transparency Portal.3

Notable exceptions to these laws are financial planning and reporting deemed to be commercially sensitive in nature or to the detriment of national security. The latter, a justification employed by the Federal Government in defence of its refusal to release details of COVID-19 Vaccine deals.4  

Monthly Financial Statements are available that show the General Budget position.5

indicators.justification:
Public Officials are obliged to disclose any conflicts of interests in written form to their government agency or the Prime Minister if they hold public office. 

There is currently a publically available register of these declarations. It is also possible to request these disclosures under the FOI Act.

Investigations into suspected misconduct are generally conducted through enquires, for example, the Inspector general of the tax office or the Auditor General, or by Federal police investigation - in recent reporting Guardian Australia, "analysed whether, absent any form of the anti-corruption body, integrity controversies were leading to other forms of inquiry or consequences for those involved. In about half the cases, they did not." The reporting cites Transparency International Australia in criticising a low investigative threshold of the proposed Commonwealth Integrity Commission, Transparency International found that potential conflicts of interest would not meet the high threshold for investigation unless there was criminal evidence.

indicators.justification:
The Lobbying Code1 and the Australian Government Statement of Ministerial Standards2 require all lobbyists are registered on the Australian Government Register of Lobbyists.3 There is no legislation. 

The register must include the details of Lobbying organizations, their contracted lobbyists, and clients only. Spending on lobbying activities or details of interactions and activities is not published on the register. Trade Unions and private (non-lobbying) organisations are not required to register.

The Australian National Audit Office conducted an audit of the report, notably they found that:

"The Register contributes to achievement of the Code's objectives but does not, on its own, provide transparency into the integrity of contact between lobbyists and Government representatives, or the matters discussed.

Parliamentary inquiries and an internal audit focused on the operation of the Register as a mechanism for providing transparency to Government representatives rather than the success of the Code in achieving all of its policy objectives.

PM&C had not established effective performance monitoring and reporting arrangements, including an evaluation strategy or plan, instead relying on internal audit and ad hoc parliamentary inquiries.

PM&C could not demonstrate it had provided advice to Government about the ongoing appropriateness of the regime since its implementation.

Public reporting about the Code was limited to answers to questions in Senate committee hearings. A Senate committee suggestion to inform the public about Code breaches was not implemented."4


Sources:

1. Australian Government, Office of the Attorney General, February 2020, Lobbying Code of Conduct, https://www.ag.gov.au/integrity/publications/lobbying-code-conduct

2. Australian Government, 2018, Statement of Ministerial Standards, https://pmc.gov.au/sites/default/files/publications/statement-ministerial-standards-3.pdf

indicators.justification:
Political Parties must self-report annually and after an election using the transparency register, Section 287N: Transparency Register, Commonwealth Electoral Act, 1918. 

A report into political finance in Australia found that the disclosure scheme is inadequate in that parties are not required to categorise receipts, meaning breaking down the types of donations and their source is very labour intensive and that the nature of self-reporting leaves the scheme open to rife under-reporting. pg 15. (1) The author of the report claims the disclosure scheme is almost designed to be ineffectual and lacks the "teeth" to kerb impropriety, while disclosures may raise suspicion - the lax reporting requirements mean only casual links are establishable in lieu of a full police investigation. pg24 (ibid, 1).

The report also indicates that political parties are flouting their obligations under the scheme with little consequence. pg. 18. (ibid, 1)

The Guardian reported that "Federally, the public is forced to wait more than a year in some cases to find out who has bankrolled the various parties.
The delay often robs voters of the information prior to casting their votes. Donations made in the lead-up to the May 2019 election, for example, were not disclosed until February 2020."2

Sources:  

1. Young, Sally and Tham, Joo Cheong. Political finance in Australia: A skewed and secret system. School of Social Sciences The Australian National University, report no 7, 2006. https://apo.org.au/sites/default/files/resource-files/2006-11/apo-nid3933.pdf

2. Knaus, Christopher. September 2020. AEC not punishing political donors that break the rules, damning audit finds, https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/sep/17/australian-electoral-commission-not-punishing-political-donors-that-break-the-rules-damning-audit-finds.

indicators.justification:
Transparency International Australia, in their submission to a review of the Australian Public Sector, point to a series of reviews and audits into Austender in summarising the lack of "accuracy, fullness, and comparability of AusTender data."pg 7 (1)

One such review, which has a broken link (https://ogpau.pmc.gov.au/commitment/43-open-contracting), is heavily criticised by Publish What You Pay Australia (PWYPA), who suggest in their response to the review; that the government deliberately avoided non-government stakeholder consultation and fails to address the key issue of non-compliance with OCDS requirements, particularly that the data be machine-readable and contain financial transactions.2 On assessing Austender, none of PWYPA's recommendations have been implemented. 

There is no evidence to suggest the government is publishing or utlising procurement data to improve either the process or access to government contracts or to support sustainable procurement. Reporting indicates the publishing framework is not robust enough to support true transparency and is suggested that this may very well be deliberate as the gas-led recovery reporting alludes to.3    

Sources:

1. Transparency International Australia, TI Australia: Submission to the Independent Review of the Australian Public Sector. July 2018, https://transparency.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/APS-Review_Transparency-International-Australia_July-2018.pdf

2. Publish What you Pay Australia, August 2017, Comment on the Review of AusTender data against the Open Contracting Data Standard, https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5dfc4510ad88600d53f93358/t/5e1bb43822ffb72e97fb13e2/1578873927669/PWYP+Australia+Submission+on+review+of+AusTender+to+OCDS.pdf

The Guardian, https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/oct/20/putins-blacklisted-oligarch-ally-to-cash-in-from-morrison-governments-gas-led-recovery?fbclid=IwAR2E3PfHumPggJQ9IHQ7xvTpRw9YCgvzxuE1ZxGlX4zPBeIYoXebcfytloA
